question: Question_02_(b)
statement:
Compute \emph{A}\textsuperscript{-1} when \emph{t} = 0, where

\[A=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 2 & t+3 \\
3 & 4 & t+1 \\
2 & 2 & t+1
\end{array}\right]\]
sols:
When \emph{t} = 0, the matrix \emph{A} is

\[A=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 2 & 3 \\
3 & 4 & 1 \\
2 & 2 & 1
\end{array}\right]\]

One way to obtain the inverse of a matrix is to row-reduce the augmented
matrix {[}A\textbar{}I{]}. Let's proceed with this method.

\[\left[A|I\right] =\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
3 & 4 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\
2 & 2 & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right]\] Perform L\textsubscript{2} →
L\textsubscript{2}-L\textsubscript{1} and L\textsubscript{3} →
L\textsubscript{3}-(2/3)L\textsubscript{1}

\[\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 2 & -2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 2/3 & -1 & -2/3 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right]\] Perform L\textsubscript{3} → 3L\textsubscript{3}

\[\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 2 & -2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 2 & -3 & -2 & 0 & 3
\end{array}\right]\] Perform L\textsubscript{3} →
L\textsubscript{3}-L\textsubscript{2}

\[\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 2 & -2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 3
\end{array}\right]\] Perform L\textsubscript{3} → (-1)L\textsubscript{3}

\[\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 2 & -2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 & -3
\end{array}\right]\] Perform L\textsubscript{1} →
L\textsubscript{1}-L\textsubscript{2} and L\textsubscript{2} →
L\textsubscript{2}+2L\textsubscript{3}

\[\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 0 & 5 & 2 & -1 & 0 \\
0 & 2 & 0 & 1 & 3 & -6 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 & -3
\end{array}\right]\] Perform L\textsubscript{1} →
L\textsubscript{1}-5L\textsubscript{3}

\[\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
3 & 0 & 0 & -3 & -6 & 15 \\
0 & 2 & 0 & 1 & 3 & -6 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 & -3
\end{array}\right]\] Perform L\textsubscript{1} →
(1/3)L\textsubscript{1} and L\textsubscript{2} → (1/2)L\textsubscript{2}

\[\sim \left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 & -1 & -2 & 5 \\
0 & 1 & 0 & 1/2 & 3/2 & -3 \\
0 & 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 & -3
\end{array}\right]\]

And we can conclude that

\[A^{-1} = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc}
-1 & -2 & 5 \\
1/2 & 3/2 & -3 \\
1 & 1 & -3
\end{array}\right]\]
hints:
There are several ways to compute the inverse of a matrix. Which ones
are you familiar with?

One way to obtain the inverse of a matrix is to row-reduce the augmented
matrix {[}\emph{A} \textbar{} \emph{I}{]}. Here \emph{I} is the
\emph{3x3} identity matrix.
